results.name: Destiny Deacon

roles_in_work.title: I Don't want to be a bludger

results.biography: Destiny Deacon is a descendant of the KuKu (Far North Queensland) and Erub/Mer (Torres Strait) people. Since the 1990s Deacon's work has been primarily involved with performative photography, exploring Indigenous identity with often provocative and humorous imagery that mocks and satirises clichéd and racist stereotypes. Partly autobiographical and partly fictitious, Deacon’s work is an insightful comedy that is effective in establishing a discourse about political, Indigenous and feminist concerns.

results.name: Josephine Starrs
results.biography: Leon Cmielewski (Adelaide, 1956) and Josephine Starrs (Adelaide, 1955), are Sydney based artists who have worked together on several projects including the interactive CD-ROM Dream Kitchen (2001), the modified computer game Bio-Tek Kitchen (2003), and the interactive installations Trace (2002), Pathfinder (2005) and Floating Territories (2005). Their work has been shown widely in Australia and Europe, including ISEA (2004) and the 2nd Beijing International New Media Exhibition & Symposium (2005). In late 2005 they spent time researching at Waag Society for Old and New Media, Amsterdam, and Sarai, Delhi. Cmielewski lectures at the School of Communication, Design & Media, University of Western Sydney, Starrs lectures at Sydney College of the Arts, University of Sydney.

roles_in_work.title: Anthony Lucas talks about 'The Cabinet of Anthony Lucas: The Faulty Fandangle'
Digital Diaries for Memory Grid Pods. Tape 1

results.name: Rony Vissers
results.biography: Johan Grimonprez’ dial H-I-S-T-O-R-Y (1997), garnered ‘best director’ awards at the San Fransisco Filmfestival and Images Toronto. Since its premiere at the Centre Georges Pompidou (Paris) and the Documenta X (Kassel), the film has travelled to numerous venues worldwide, and is now released on home-DVD, accompanied by contributions from novelist Don Delillo and cultural theorist, Slavoj Zizek; distributed by D.A.P. (New York) and Imageforum (Tokyo). A current faculty member at the School of Visual Arts (New York), Johan Grimonprez’ work resides at the Tate Modern (London), the Kanazawa Art Museum (Japan), and is acquired by Channel 4 (U.K.) and Arte (Germany/France).  He has curated new media projects for venues such as the Musee d’Art Moderne (Paris) and the Whitney Museum (New York); and published Inflight (2000) with Hatje/Cantz (Germany). His website www.zapomatik.com investigates our curious habit of zapping in relation to the commercial break. ZAP-O-MATIK will also produce his new film ZUNK® currently being developed at the Maurits Binger Film Institute (Amsterdam) and supported by the Flemish Filmfund (VAF, Brussels).DECEMBER 2004

results.name: Johan Grimonprez
results.biography: Johan Grimonprez’ dial H-I-S-T-O-R-Y (1997), garnered ‘best director’ awards at the San Fransisco Filmfestival and Images Toronto. Since its premiere at the Centre Georges Pompidou (Paris) and the Documenta X (Kassel), the film has travelled to numerous venues worldwide, and is now released on home-DVD, accompanied by contributions from novelist Don Delillo and cultural theorist, Slavoj Zizek; distributed by D.A.P. (New York) and Imageforum (Tokyo). A current faculty member at the School of Visual Arts (New York), Johan Grimonprez’ work resides at the Tate Modern (London), the Kanazawa Art Museum (Japan), and is acquired by Channel 4 (U.K.) and Arte (Germany/France).  He has curated new media projects for venues such as the Musee d’Art Moderne (Paris) and the Whitney Museum (New York); and published Inflight (2000) with Hatje/Cantz (Germany). His website www.zapomatik.com investigates our curious habit of zapping in relation to the commercial break. ZAP-O-MATIK will also produce his new film ZUNK® currently being developed at the Maurits Binger Film Institute (Amsterdam) and supported by the Flemish Filmfund (VAF, Brussels). CURRENT AT DECEMBER 2004
